#Text=CHAPTER XVI
#Text=George Waldeaux took his mother and boy back to the old homestead in Delaware .
#Text=They arrived at night , and early the next morning he rowed away in his bateau to some of his old haunts in the woods on the bay , and was seen no more that day .
#Text=" He is inconsolable ! " his mother told some of her old neighbors who crowded to welcome her .
#Text=" His heart is in that grave in Vannes . "
#Text=The women listened in surprise , for Frances was not in the habit of exploiting her emotions in words .
#Text=" We understood , " said one of them , with a sympathetic shake of the head , " that it was a pure love match .

#Text= I never thought her -- but I ca n't discuss Lisa ! "

column1: #Text=She was silent a moment .
#Text=" But as for her social position" -- she drew herself up stiffly , fixing cold defiant eyes on her questioner --
#Text="as for her social position , " she went on resolutely , " she was descended on one side from an excellent American family , and on the other from one of the noblest houses in Europe . "
#Text=When they were gone she hugged little Jacques passionately as he lay on her lap .
#Text=" That is settled for you ! " she said .
#Text=When George came back in the evening , he found her walking with the boy in her arms on the broad piazzas .
#Text=" I really think he knows that he has come home , George ! " she exclaimed .
#Text=" See how he laughs !

#Text= Give the child to Colette , mother , and listen to me .

column1: #Text=She followed him into the hall .
#Text=" I leave you to-morrow .

#Text= I did not mean to remind you of -- of -- -- "

column1: #Text=" No , it is n't that ! "
#Text=He scowled at the fire .

#Text=Art meant for him his own countless daubs , and the sickening smell of oily paints and musk , and soiled silk tea gowns , and the whole slovenly , disreputable scramble of Bohemian life in Paris .
#Text=" I loathe art ! " he said , with a furious blow at the smouldering log in the fireplace , as if he struck these things all down into the ashes with it .
#Text=" Will you go back into the Church , dear ? " his mother ventured timidly .
#Text=" Most certainly , no ! " he said vehemently .
#Text=" Of all mean frauds the perfunctory priest is the meanest .
#Text=" I am sure of it , " she interrupted eagerly .
#Text=" But I must deliver it in my own way .

#Text= And in the meantime , of course , I must make money enough to support you and the boy handsomely .

column1: #Text=It was the proudest moment of her life .
#Text=How heroic and generous he was !
#Text=She filled his pocket-book the next day , when he went to New York to take the world by the throat .
#Text=It was really not George Waldeaux 's fault that she filled it .
#Text=Nor was it his fault that during the next two years the world was in no hurry to run to his feet , either to learn of him , or to bring him its bags of gold .
#Text=The little man did his best ; he put his " message , " as he called it , into poems , into essays , into a novel .
#Text=Publishers thanked him effusively for the pleasure of reading them , and -- sent them back .
#Text=The only word of his which reached the public was a review of the work of a successful author .
#Text=It was so personal , so malignant , that George , when he read it , writhed with shame and humiliation .
#Text=He tore the paper into fragments .
#Text=" Am I so envious and small as that !

#Text=Before God , no words of mine shall ever go into print again !  he said , and he kept his word .

column1: #Text=" These great scholars and scientific men have places and reputations which even you need not despise . "
#Text=He laughed bitterly .
#Text=" I tried for a place as tutor in a third-class school , and could not pass the examinations .
